sense.name: a measure of physical strength or power
sense.examples: Physicists have wondered why gravity is such a weak force compared to the other three forces. It was measured as a Force 10 hurricane on the Beaufort scale. The truck hit the wall with great force. We used all our force to lift the boat onto the trailer. The force of a 44 Magnum's bullet going through the skull would not leave such a small hole as this.

sense.name: a military or disciplinary body
sense.examples: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff oversees all the armed forces. Bob retired from the police force last year. Napoleon's forces were fatally weakened by the Russian winter. They sent a force of ten thousand men into the battlefield.

sense.name: causal agent, often powerful, usually abstract
sense.commentary: FORCE[+causal][+agent][+powerful] Note: can be human, but does not imply this.
sense.examples: In the chess world, he is a force to be reckoned with. The spiritualists thought they felt the presence of an evil force in the room. Those are forces beyond anyone's control. Economists predict the industry's pricing will succumb to the forces of the free market.

sense.name: a group, usually people, that is available for a societal purpose
sense.commentary: FORCE[+group][+social][+utility] Note: Sense 4 does -not- imply the group advocates anything, making it different from Sense 7
sense.examples: Immigrants provide a continuous boost to the labor forces of low birthrate nations. They've organized a task force to look into this problem. Their company has had two reductions in force this year. The treaty specifies reducing the missile force by fifty percent in five years. Young people entering the work force today face global competition.

sense.name: the quality of being impressive or effective
sense.examples: There is no force to his argument. The force of his portrait paintings lies in the expressiveness of the subjects' eyes. In that film John portrays an aging playwright with force and conviction.

sense.name: physical aggression or violence
sense.examples: The military leaders expected the force of shock and awe to subdue the enemy. If negotiations break down the two countries may resort to force. The terrorists took the women by force.

sense.name: social organization that advocates something, often effectively
sense.examples: MADD has been a grassroots force to strengthen and enforce the laws against drunk driving. Several political groups are joining forces to orchestrate a big demonstration next week. These days too many politicians are being influenced by lobbyists and other forces around Washington.

sense.name: a state of validity or being in effect
sense.examples: This ruling will remain in force unless it is overturned by new legislation. The dress code is still in force at the French restaurant downtown. There was a curfew in force last month during the riots.

sense.name: an obligatory play in baseball
sense.examples: The runner was out by a force at third base. The shortstop made a force at second, ending the inning.

sense.name: in great numbers
sense.examples: Picnickers were out in force on the beautiful Saturday afternoon. The glitterati appeared in force on opening night of the new Broadway musical.
